description:
Running essex-rc1 on ubuntu 12.04

On diablo the following would work

nova-manage floating create 131.227.76.235/32
root@cloud-cc:~# nova-manage floating create 131.227.75.201/32

root@cloud-cc:~# nova-manage floating list | grep 75.201
None	131.227.75.201	None

allowing you to add one IP address at a time, very hand for people with limited control over their networks.

In essex-rc1 this has stopped working

root@kvm-dev01:~# nova-manage floating create 131.227.76.235/32

root@kvm-dev01:~# nova-manage floating list
2012-03-26 12:17:45 DEBUG nova.utils [req-79fdff8f-65a9-4407-99e0-17cd768a1b71 None None] backend <module 'nova.db.sqlalchemy.api' from '/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/nova/db/sqlalchemy/api.pyc'> from (pid=6355) __get_backend /usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/nova/utils.py:660
No floating IP addresses have been defined.

Seems the smallest network I can now add is a /30

Kind Regards
John

comments.content:
That code has since been changed. See #951161

Basically, /32 and /31 don't make any sense. See http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc1122

            IP addresses are not permitted to have the value 0 or -1 for
            any of the <Host-number>, <Network-number>, or <Subnet-
            number> fields (except in the special cases listed above).
            This implies that each of these fields will be at least two
            bits long.

Any range has the host-numbers of all zeros and all 1s reserved, so /30 is the smallest that has these reserved and still has address available for allocation in the range

We still support allocating a single IP just by specifying that IP:

  $> nova-manage floating create 131.227.76.235
